abstract.p: Ellen Kanner and Andrew Romanelli letters on Lesley Jane Seymour's April 22 article on pre-teen shoppers

block.p: ''Tweens 'R' Shoppers'' (April 22), Lesley Jane Seymour's account of the tween shopping craze, seems unduly kind. The mall can be romanticized as a place for ''sophisticated, thoughtful, opinionated'' consumers to try on ''identities and selves.''

More realistically, however, given Ms. Seymour's observation that most tweens flock to major brands like Abercrombie & Fitch and American Eagle Outfitters, the trend represents exactly the opposite: the desire to be just like everyone else.

''Tweens 'R' Shoppers'' (April 22), Lesley Jane Seymour's account of the tween shopping craze, seems unduly kind. The mall can be romanticized as a place for ''sophisticated, thoughtful, opinionated'' consumers to try on ''identities and selves.''

More realistically, however, given Ms. Seymour's observation that most tweens flock to major brands like Abercrombie & Fitch and American Eagle Outfitters, the trend represents exactly the opposite: the desire to be just like everyone else.

If young adults feel the need to be part of ''a larger club,'' as one parent put it, why not find real clubs where they might learn a skill or cultivate a talent? In so doing, perhaps parents can help their children discover that their ''identities and selves'' have little to do with what handbags they carry.

The role of a parent is not to create an ''incredibly sophisticated, thoughtful, opinionated consumer'' who contributes to our economy, but to create an incredibly sophisticated, thoughtful, caring individual who contributes to our society.
The pressure on young children to be indoctrinated into our excessively materialistic consumer culture is unrelenting. Parents should protect their children from this pressure, not reinforce it.
